general: This law makes sure that the people who work at the Crown Prosecution Service are checked to see if they are doing their jobs well. It's like having someone come in to look over how things are being done, so that everyone can be sure that everything is running smoothly and fairly.

series.short: "Attorney General Oversight of Crown Prosecution Service"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The Attorney General appoints a Chief Inspector of the Crown Prosecution Service to oversee the service's operations.
* Simplified point 2: The Chief Inspector can hire staff and make expenses claims to carry out their duties, which include inspecting the CPS and reporting to the Attorney General.
* Simplified point 3: The Chief Inspector must submit an annual report to the Attorney General on the CPS's operations.
* Simplified point 4: The Attorney General must present any reports received from the Chief Inspector to Parliament.
* Simplified point 5: The Chief Inspector can delegate their duties to an inspector during absences or incapacity.

summary: The Crown Prosecution Service Inspectorate Act 2000 ensures that the Crown Prosecution Service (CPS) operates effectively and efficiently. It sets up an independent body called the Crown Prosecution Service Inspectorate, led by a Chief Inspector appointed by the Attorney General. The Inspectorate conducts regular inspections of the CPS and submits annual reports to the Attorney General and Parliament. This helps maintain high standards within the CPS and holds them accountable for their actions. Additionally, the Act allows the Chief Inspector to hire staff and claim expenses to support their work, providing necessary resources for effective oversight. Overall, the Crown Prosecution Service Inspectorate Act 2000 promotes transparency and accountability within the CPS, ultimately benefiting those who rely on the justice system.
single:
•	The Crown Prosecution Service Inspectorate Act 2000 establishes an inspectorate to oversee the Crown Prosecution Service (CPS) in England and Wales.
•	The Attorney General appoints a Chief Inspector to lead the inspectorate and can appoint other inspectors and staff to assist.
•	The Chief Inspector is responsible for inspecting the CPS and reporting to the Attorney General on any matters connected with its operation.
•	The Chief Inspector submits an annual report to the Attorney General on the operation of the CPS.
•	The Attorney General must lay the annual report before Parliament.
•	The Chief Inspector can designate an inspector to act on their behalf during absences or incapacity.
•	The Act only applies to England and Wales.
•	The Act came into force on a date appointed by the Attorney General through a statutory instrument.
